Sure, even your unaided eyes. When astronomers where trying to figure out the characteristics of the Milky Way, before we understood about external galaxies, star counts were the way to quantize the distribution of stars in our galaxy. Photographic plates were taken, marked off in squares, & the number of stars of each brightness were tabulated. Because of the grading of star images was based on the size of the tiny images, it was often called “fly spanking”. Star counting was really boring work.

Yes. We can definitely count stars. And this is a task that astronomers very often do in images. There are softwares that are specifically designed to measure the fluxes of stars even in very crowded fields such globular clusters are, for example. All you need is a digital image and a proper software (such as “daophot”).
